title: Timely Semantics: A Study of a Stream-based Ranking System for Entity Relationships

author: Lorenz Fischer, Department of Informatics, University of Zurich

segmentation: Hello, thank you very much for coming.
Thanks for having me.
My name is Lawrence.
I'm from the University of Zurich and I'm going to present you study that we did in.
Nation with Yahoo Labs in particular with Roy Blanco and Peter Mika and obviously my advisor.
Also a Bernstein also from the University of Zurich.
Um, the topic is is a study that we did not.
We evaluated how what the value is of doing entity ranking fast.
And I want to start out by first defining what I mean by entity ranking.
So, given an entity a, the process of entity ranking is how to order entities B2.
E In a way, so that the most important entity of these relationships is going to be on top and the least important entity that shares a relationship to a is on the bottom.
To be a bit more concrete and also to give you the Canonical example of this is you have Brad Pitt.
And then you have a couple of related celebrities and also movies and you want to order them in a way that is most meaningful for this task.
The reason why you want to do this is, for example in web.
Search were most modern web search engines nowadays have info boxes on the right.
And within these info.
Boxes you didn't have.
Certain entities that you might want to rank in order of importance another application might.
Be in traveling.
Or you might have an entity here Paris and then you have related point.
Interests entities again that you want to rank to recommend to tourists travelling.
One way to arrive at such NT.
The rankings is to use a volatile user generated data source.
Which is for example search logs.
You can then use the search log.
In combination with semantic Web data that you retrieve from knowledge base and then.
Much Tehmina data mining process to arrive at good rankings, and this is precisely what.
Paper of Roy.
Actually in Peter two years ago presented at ISTC as well.
This is a system that does this and what we did for this study is take.

This system and reimplement certain aspects of it to make it fast and by having it fast we were able to reduce the latency between data collection and rank generation and then the question that we were asking in this study is.
How much does this bias in terms of better recommendations in terms of relevance and but also in fresh in terms of freshness?
The study.
Is roughly can be divided in these three parts.
First I would like to show you how this entity ranking pipeline works to fresh things up.
Then I'm going to talk quickly about data and then about the evaluation that we did.

This is from the original paper.
The Entity Ranking pipeline is roughly functioning three steps you have.
A feature generation step where.
As I mentioned you process search log data in the original system also.
Processed processes, tweets, and also Flickr image tags.
It searches for entities, these entities, together with the information that comes from the Knowledge base order.
And munched into a set of features, and these features are then used in the model learning phase.
This is sorry.

To be concrete, it's a gradient boosted decision tree model in this case, and.
Having this model, this model obviously needs some labeled data, and we retrieve those from editors, so these are professionals hired by Yahoo.

With the features that we have also, the features for unlabeled data, we can then produce.

Computationally intensive, is this part.
Here is the feature extraction phase where you have to process large amounts of data and This is why we then replace.
The Hadoop implementation that was in place at the time with a storm implementation.
For those of you who don't know, storm really quickly explained to you what storm is.
Storm is a distributed stream processing framework, meaning you can write applications that then run on your clusters.
This works roughly as follows.
You can think of a topology, a storm application as something so.
Or two, an assembly line in a factory.
Each worker does one single task and then passes this object down to the next worker in line.
And similarly, a topology is directed acyclic graph where we have each node processing doing one step of the processing.
In contrast to an assembly line, however, here you can parallelize each of these nodes.
And then arrive at.
You can basically create clones of your workers and distribute those across.
Cluster and this is where the parallelism comes from.

For the preprocessing, we first read the data.
We use HDF's for this and it.
Diately after we apply for the first time semantic web information.
To be concrete, we filter out all the entities, all the entity pairs for which there is no meaningful connection in our knowledge base.
And then after this we do counting.
So we count how many times do we see entity.
How many times do we see Entity B and how many times do we see them together?
So it's called Co occurrence statistics also and this info.

And is then used in phase two where we generate a couple of features, most simple ones or probability estimate estimations or also conditional probability estimates or more fancy ones such as entropy, KL, divergent, or cosine similarity.
Again, if you want to get the full list of all of these features, I refer you to the paper of Roy and Peter.
It's a great paper.

Last step is then we do the ranking actually and we again documents the features that we extracted from the search logs with semantic web information and here it's mostly entity types but also the type of the relationship between those entities that we take as one feature.
Then we pass this into our model to get the ranking.
The data that we used for our evaluation was then, so we went out and collected different datasets.
And since this is a machine learning pipeline, we wanted to have different sizes of datasets.
We decided on taking 30 days worth of search log data.
Seven days worth of search log data, and only one day worth of search log data.

I think it was January 21, yes, so this was the day where we actually ran the evaluation.
And in a day.
With these three datasets, we collected six additional datasets cutoff date at January 12 and then.
Cutoff date is January 31 and this.
We named those data sets for the later slides, new, recent and old data, and this is.
Actually we compare fast processing versus slow processing because only if you have a system that can process this data really fast, you can actually use up-to-date data to produce your rankings.
And if your system is not so fast, then your data might be a bit old by the time we actually arrive at your rankings, could be 10 days old or here in the worst case even 20 days old.

Created models and then having the models again with the.

We can then.

Delete how good are we and the evaluation we did as follows.

We wanted to have real world queries and again because this is fresh data where we don't have any prior knowledge about, we needed the help of our editor editors to tell us how well we did in terms of freshness, but also in terms of relevance.
Query selection, so we had to select a bunch of queries and we couldn't just take all the queries that ran on one day because this would have been way too much data so.

We selected the top 60 queries that we could find for each day having entities in them and the reason for this is that assuming many people search for something, this entity might have would gain profit from having recent results shown in the sidebar for it.
For D60 queer.
